current_subquestions: Q1: Identify the cells that are surrounded by the same color on all four sides.

If all four neighbors have the same color as the current cell, then the current cell is surrounded by the same color on all four sides.
A2: For the cells that are surrounded by the same color on all four sides, we should change the color of the cell to the color of the surrounding cells.

current_subquestions: Q1: Identify the cells that are surrounded by the same color on all four sides.
Q2: Determine the color of the surrounding cells.
Q3: Change the color of the identified cells to the color of the surrounding cells.
Q4: Repeat the process for all colors present in the grid.
new_subanswers_ys:
A1: To identify the cells that are surrounded by the same color on all four sides, we can iterate through each cell in the grid. For each cell, we check its top, bottom, left, and right neighbors. If all four neighbors have the same color as the current cell, then the current cell is surrounded by the same color on all four sides. 
A2: To determine the color of the surrounding cells, we can simply check the color of any one of the neighboring cells that we identified in the previous step. Since we know that all four neighbors have the same color, the color of any one of them will be the color of the surrounding cells.
A3: To change the color of the identified cells to the color of the surrounding cells, we can simply assign the color of the surrounding cells to the current cell in our iteration. This can be done using an assignment operation in our code.
A4: To repeat the process for all colors present in the grid, we can create a loop that iterates through each unique color present in the grid. For each iteration, we perform the steps outlined in the previous subquestions. This ensures that we identify and change the color of all cells that are surrounded by the same color on all four sides, for each color present in the grid.

A1: To identify the cells that are surrounded by the same color on all four sides, we can iterate through each cell in the grid. For each cell, we check its top, bottom, left, and right neighbors. If all four neighbors have the same color as the current cell, then the current cell is surrounded by the same color on all four sides. 
A2: To determine the color of the surrounding cells, we can simply check the color of any one of the neighboring cells that we identified in the previous step. Since we know that all four neighbors have the same color, the color of any one of them will be the color of the surrounding cells.
A3: To change the color of the identified cells to the color of the surrounding cells, we can simply assign the color of the surrounding cells to the current cell in our iteration. This can be done using an assignment operation in our code.
A4: To repeat the process for all colors present in the grid, we can use a nested loop. The outer loop iterates through each unique color present in the grid. For each color, the inner loop iterates through each cell in the grid and performs the steps outlined in the previous subquestions. This ensures that the process is repeated for all colors and all cells in the grid.
